ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Improvement of Chinese grammar, increased vocabulary, and more confidence speaking Chinese.

So many! I came into this class with very little writing and reading skills in Mandarin (practically none), and over the course of this semester, I have learned to read and write short paragraphs. I also have expanded my vocabulary and fostered my speaking confidence.
I learned a lot about Chinese language and culture.

I came in not being able to write a lick of Chinese, but I was able to speak and read some. I was able to learn 300-500 Chinese characters by the end of the course as well as improve my speaking skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course is taught well as is.

Strengths: very steep learning curve and daily progress. 
Weaknesses: the first few weeks constituted one of my toughest learning experiences ever because the course advanced incredibly fast, and during this time I felt quite disheartened.
The small class size and ample support structures were really big strengths of this course.

Strengths: fast pace of the course. You really have to practice every single day for the quizzes
Weeaknesses: not enough opportunities for students to practice speaking to each other and to the teacher. Class is mainly listening to the lecture with some practice in between. The tutoring program is also unnecessary. I felt like I needed to sit there for 30 minutes with the tutor and try to fill in the time with small talk.
I really appreciated the teacher. Sometimes the weekly quizzes were a bit intense.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but only if you have previous Chinese experience (specifically in listening, not so much in talking or writing).
Yes! If you are committed to your Chinese improvement and are ready to put in a lot of work (and only then!), you will see your Chinese improve by a lot over the course of the semester.
Yes! Chen Laoshi is amazing and each class was very engaging. It was very satisfying to see my Chinese skills improve vastly over the course of the semester.
Yes, if you speak chinese at home but can't write at all or if you speak chinglish and want to improve.
